utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We are condemned to useless labor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fourth circle of Hell. Charting goes a lot faster when you eliminate the whole of classic poetry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Writing down what we already know to be read by nobody. Pretty sure Dante would agree that qualifies as useless.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re over two weeks behind on your charting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oops. I missed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you, eight?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could an eight-year-old do this?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You better stop or it’ll stick that way. You have a patient in Exam Room 1.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but see, see, I’m off at twelve and it’s already five of.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s been waiting for you since eleven.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Melancholy without hope. Which circle is that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi. I’m Dr. House. What seems to be the problem?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You must be all the talk around the holy water cooler. You been washing a lot of dishes recently?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Anything new in the kitchen?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Should have spent your time saving souls, it’s easier on the hands. This is contact dermatitis; you’re allergic to dish soap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve been a doctor for years. Why do I have to keep assuring people that I know what I’m doing? A person can become allergic to substances that they’ve had repeated and prolonged exposure to. The good news is: free samples. Diphenhydramine. It’s an antihistamine. It’ll stop the allergic reaction. Take one every eight hours, it might make you feel a little sleepy. And get some of that over-the-counter cortisone cream.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want some water?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you just relax for a few minutes. That stuff works pretty fast.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Still out by twelve.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you solve a problem like dermatitis?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She talking to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t know. She’s certainly looking at me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you don’t? Then you’re wearing an awfully funny hat.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oooh, boy. Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lift up your chin. Sister, you’re having an asthma attack. I need you to relax. Roll up her sleeve, please. I’m giving you epinephrine, it’ll open your lungs and help you breathe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did she take the pill?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s probably an allergic reaction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You figure somebody’s out to get her? How’re you feeling?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll put you on some steroids instead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s called adrenaline, it makes your heart beat fast. But not this fast. Get a nurse, please. Lie back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Somebody get in here! Call a code and charge up a defibrillator. She’s got no pulse.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You diagnosed the patient with allergies and prescribed antihistamine, she went into respiratory distress, and you injected her with epinephrine. Presumably 1 cc.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 0.1 cc. That is the standard dose, that is what I gave her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: People don’t go into cardiac arrest from 0.1 cc epinephrine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She must have a pre-existing heart condition that got exacerbated by the epinephrine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s too bad you didn’t make a notation in the chart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can make it up right now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The drawer has syringes with both dosages, you could have easily reached for the wrong one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But I didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Everyone makes mistakes. This is why doctors pay through the nose for malpractice insurance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax, they’re not going to sue. Worse they’d do is whack my hand with a ruler.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And the discipline board? Are they gonna whack your hand, too?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re going to report me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What choice do I have?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, how ‘bout not report me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can justify keeping her here for 24-hour observation. If you haven’t found an underlying cause for the cardiac arrest by then I will have to notify our attorneys.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her hands were red and swollen, maybe she has a skin infection. Cellulitis? That could manifest with tachycardia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s no history of fever. Results from the CBC didn’t indicate an infection.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The eosinophils were mildly elevated, sed rate’s up a bit. Could be looking at a systemic allergic response.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not allergic. Allergies don’t cause cardiac arrest like this. Could be inflammation of the blood vessels.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Vasculitis? That wouldn’t give you an elevated eosinophil count.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Churg-Strauss vasculitis would. Blood vessels of the heart, lungs and skin become inflamed causing the asthma, rash and heart problems. Covers all her symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Need a biopsy to diagnose.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Chest CT’d be quicker.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The lady just came in with a rash.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What the hell are those?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Candy canes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Candy canes? Are you mocking me?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No! It’s Christmas and, and I, I, I thought –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. It’s a joke.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Isn’t the prognosis for Churg-Strauss a bit grim?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah. Untreated only 33% of patients survive past a year; treated, five years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then I’d definitely suggest treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If it was any other attending doctor, I’d say that he made a mistake and gave her too much epinephrine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Saying you wouldn’t say it was my mistake is saying it was my mistake.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Everyone screws up: your rule. I think you fit inside the subset of “everyone”.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn’t screw up. Order a chest CT and start the sister on prednisone, 40 mg. TID.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The sister?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, didn’t I mention? The patient’s a nun. Sister Augustine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Aw. I hate nuns.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who doesn’t?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sister Augustine?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: We weren’t watching.

utterance.speaker: Pius
utterance.content: We were trying to see if this was the bed control.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, um, this one’s the bed control and that one’s the TV control. I’m Dr. Cameron, and that’s Dr. Chase and Dr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I hadn’t seen television in over twenty years.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Do you consider it the work of the devil, or do you just not get cable where you live?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Um, how’re you feeling, Sister?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I seem to be a little better; they gave me some medication.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Prednisone. It’s a steroid to help with the inflammation.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Has Dr. House figured out what I have? Will I be okay?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re not sure what’s wrong yet. You’ll have a chest CT scan this afternoon that will help with the diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Pius
utterance.content: Dr. House is giving her medication and he doesn’t know what she has yet?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Trust, Sister Pius. It all happens for a reason.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t know what he’s doing. The only problem that woman has is that House grabbed the wrong syringe.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don’t trust him?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t trust a man who won’t admit he might be wrong. I notice you weren’t so quick to tell her she has Churg-Strauss and only has a couple years to live.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t tell patients bad news unless it’s conclusive.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Because you know he might be wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: About Churg-Strauss, not about what happened in the clinic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about you, Chase? You think he’s infallible, too?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All I know is, if House didn’t make a mistake and Sister Augustine has Churg-Strauss, he’ll be self-satisfied and our lives will be good for a few weeks. If House did make a mistake, he’ll be upset and our lives will be miserable for months.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There is that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If Cuddy thinks I made a mistake the least she could do is suspend me from clinic duty.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She doesn’t confuse making a mistake with being incompetent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, here we go. Lesson time. I recognize that confidence is not my short suit. I also recognize that I am human and capable of error.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So you might have screwed this up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So, it’s only a theoretical capacity for error.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good point. Maybe there isn’t one. Maybe that’s my error.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You know, most people who think as much of themselves as you do like to talk about themselves.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Most people don’t like to listen, so what’s wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let me guess… inflammatory bowel.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: Wow, yeah. Is it that bad?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. It’s also written on your chart. Bloody diarrhea, gas, pain… took sulfasalazine, but it didn’t work –

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: No, then I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Next tried steroid enemas, oral corticosteroids, 5ASAs, 6 mercaptopurine… I’m impressed.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: By my medical history?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: By how well your last doctor charted.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: It’s one thing to have to go to the bathroom every hour, but when the kids sit on my lap, it’s…. The store sent me home, they’re gonna fire me. Can’t you put me back on 5ASA? Maybe it’ll work this time?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not likely. I’m giving you a prescription. It’s cheap, which is good because your insurance company won’t pay for it.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: Cojorius?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cigarettes. One twice a day, no more, no less. Studies have shown that cigarette smoking is one of the most effective ways to control inflammatory bowel, plus it’s been established that you look 30% cooler.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: Are you kidding me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: About the looking cooler, yeah. The rest is true.

utterance.speaker: Santa
utterance.content: Isn’t it addictive and dangerous?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pretty much all the drugs I prescribe are addictive and dangerous. The difference with this one is that it’s completely legal. Merry Christmas.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I was talking to the nurse, Arsenio. Do you know him?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not really.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: He can take pictures with his phone.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cool.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: That woman from the lab was interesting, too. She studied astrophysics before becoming a nurse.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You know the staff better than I do.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Well, I love to hear about people.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yet you live in a monastery.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: It’s where I serve our Lord and the world best.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Our Lord, maybe. The rest of the world, on the other hand, would probably get more out of feeding the homeless or –

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Healing the sick?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: As an example, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Did you always want to be a doctor?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Always. You always want to be a nun?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: My parents died when I was six. I was raised in a foster home run by the Church. When I was eighteen, I went to the monastery where they let me take my vows. I’ve known no other life and I haven’t wanted to.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay, Sister, we need to you lie as still as possible. If you get scared, just let us know.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: As Jonah said from inside the whale, “When I had lost all hope, I turned my thoughts to the Lord.”

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: At least she’s got God on her side.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t believe in God.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not even a little agnostic?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Is it supposed to smell funny?

utterance.speaker: Tech
utterance.content: Someone ralphed in there this afternoon. We cleaned it up, but…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s normal, Sister. It’s just a few more minutes. I believe in a higher order that’s in control of what happens, but not one anthropomorphic entity called “God” that’s concerned with the everyday workings of you and me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What else is there to control but the everyday workings of you and me?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s always about you, Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What else are you talking about? The trees, the fish? Should they be the ones to think it’s all about them? What about you, Chase? Do you believe in God?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I believe Sister Augustine has no vascular pathology, which means no Churg-Strauss.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which means House made a mistake.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, not necessarily. It could be something else. Thyrotoxicosis or a carcinoid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t get you. You don’t believe in God, but you’re willing to put complete faith in one man?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Please, the smell!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Let’s get her out of there.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m coming, Sister. I gotcha, I’m coming.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Please, please, the smell, I’m sick –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s no smell –

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: No, God, no – Oh, it’s Jesus! It’s Jesus! He’s coming for me. He’s burning me with his touch!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Let’s get her on some Ativan. Smells, religious visions are symptomatic of temporal lobe swelling. We don’t want her to –

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Oh!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s seizing!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Help me get her on her side.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Religious visions?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah. And next comes…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Patient tested positive for herpetic encephalitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what’s that tell us?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her immune system is severely compromised.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ooh, I know! Prednisone compromises the immune system. Isn’t that the medicine you gave her for the thing she doesn’t have?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but… hey. I’m think that’s a trick question.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her immune system is severely compromised. Two doses of prednisone wouldn’t do that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you hanging your diagnosis on an adverb?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In ten seconds I’m gonna announce that I gave her the wrong dose in the clinic.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re gonna admit negligence?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless you leave the room. If you stay you’ll have to testify. Five, four, three, two…. So, there I was in the clinic, drunk. I open the drawer, close my eyes, take the first syringe I can find – So, what are the options for compromised immune system?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mixed connective tissue disease. It’d explain why she was feeling better on the prednisone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sure, she was feeling better right up to the moment it almost killed her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On the other hand, it explains the symptoms. Swollen hands, pulmonary problems, cardiac problems – it all fits.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Except her ANA was normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So redraw the blood.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But the treatment is corticosteroids, prednisone, and we can’t go there because of the encephalitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then we’ll treat it with something that modulates the immune system but doesn’t suppress it. Hyperbaric oxygen chamber.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s no protocol for putting a patient in a high-pressure oxygen room to treat autoimmune problems.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, you people. Always with the protocols. Prep the nun and discontinue the prednisone. I am both amused and annoyed that you think I should be less stubborn than you are.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You are aware of the Hippocratic Oath, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The one that starts: First, do no harm, then goes on to tell us no abortions, no seductions, and definitely no cutting of those who labor beneath the stone. Yeah, took a read once, wasn’t impressed.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hyperbaric treatments could cause oxygen toxicity, lung and eye damage –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Every treatment has its dangers –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which is why we treat when we’re only convinced the patient needs the treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m convinced. You’re not. Question is, what are you going to do about it? Hmm?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have an opening Thursday at three. Do you have a fourth? Is he any good? Can I call you right back? Okay. What’s up?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The pressure will force the oxygen into your system and saturate your blood. It will enhance white cell activity and reduce the inflammation.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: And that will help with this mixed connective tissue disease?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll be doing about ten treatments and then we’ll reevaluate.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: The last treatment with prednisone caused the seizures, right? How confident is Dr. House about this?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That you reacted so strongly to the prednisone let us know that you had an underlying problem with your immune system.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I guess it was a blessing… of sorts.

utterance.speaker: Soap Doc
utterance.content: So, who’s your favorite reindeer, Nurse ?

utterance.speaker: Soap Nurse
utterance.content: Rudolph.

utterance.speaker: Soap Doc
utterance.content: I would have thought it was Vixen.

utterance.speaker: Soap Nurse
utterance.content: What are you implying?

utterance.speaker: Soap Doc
utterance.content: Nothing, but I saw you at the Christmas party with Dr.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: This is a chapel. A house of prayer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: House of prayer, huh. That explains the good reception. Also why nobody’s ever here.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: I need to talk with you, Dr. House. Sister Augustine believes in things that aren’t real.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought that was a job requirement for you people.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: She’s been known to lie to get sympathy. She’s a hypochondriac.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, you’re warning me that I may be treating a non-existent ailment

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: Sore throats, joint pains… there’s always something wrong, and there’s never a reason for it. Mother Superior plays right into it. Lets Augustine off work duties, treating her as fragile, special.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That must make you angry.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: It bothers me. It’s not really in Augustine’s best interests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Want some?

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: I shouldn’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I guess you’ve got to be good at reading people to be a good infirmarian, huh.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: Mm hmm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, we’ve got pride, anger, envy, gluttony…. That’s four out of seven deadly sins in two minutes. Do you people keep records of these things? Is there a Cathlympics?

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: They say you have a gift.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They like to talk.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: You hide behind your intelligence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s pretty stupid.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: And you make jokes because you’re afraid to take anything seriously. Because if you take things seriously, they matter, and if they matter –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And when things go wrong, I get hurt. I’m not tough, I’m vulnerable.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: I barely know you, and I don’t know if I’m right. I just hope I am. Because the alternative is, you really are as miserable as you seem to be.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, from the way you’re looking at me right now, I’d say you just hit number five: lust.

utterance.speaker: Soap Nurse
utterance.content: Dr. Brown, I love you, too.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How’re you feeling?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: A little weak.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s from the oxygen.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: My mouth is dry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Okay. well, I’ll get you some of your tea.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mixed connective tissue disease? Her ANA is barely elevated!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, thanks for checking up on her. Good to know you’ve got my back.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 0-2 stat is down to 83, pulmonary problems, breathing problems –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Irritation from the oxygen is typical.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She comes in with a rash and you put her into cardiac arrest.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That well just never runs dry, does it? If there was no underlying problem, then why is she still having the rapid heartrate?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Maybe from the herpetic encephalitis caused by you giving her prednisone!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her reaction is a symptom, not an error.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There’s always an explanation, isn’t there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, there is! And if this one doesn’t work will find another.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: But never one involving you screwing up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One that fits all the facts. Look, we obviously have a difference of opinion, and that’s fine, but unfortunately I’ve used up all the time I’ve budgeted today for banging my head against a wall.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am going to do you the biggest favor one doctor can do for another. I am going to stop you from killing your patient. You’re off the case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’re going to treat the symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not the underlying condition?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There is no underlying condition. What’s her status?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The sister’s breathing is labored.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Pneumonitis from the hyperbaric chamber. Put her on 40% oxygen until her 0-2 stats increase.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: BUN and creatinine’s rising, ALT and AST twice the normal range.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Could be from the hypertensive episode. Let’s follow them with labs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She still has the rash and the joint pain she came in with.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Order a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: When we were looking at the differential diagnosis with Dr. House, we were considering –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don’t need to hear what Dr. House was considering! All of this woman’s symptoms can be traced to Dr. House’s considerations. Okay. Let’s just get this patient healthy. I want her going out the front door, and not the back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, it’s not like I betrayed him. Cuddy would have found out about the hyperbaric treatments eventually.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You did what you felt you had to.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Can’t get enough of this place, huh?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Came for my stethoscope.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So, I shouldn’t read too much into the fact that you were looking for it in the drawer with the epinephrine syringes in it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, yeah. I’d like to clear my reputation.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, right. I forgot that you care about what people think. Prescribing cigarettes for inflammatory bowel? It could cause lung cancer, you know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know why they have ribbons for breast cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer and not for lung cancer?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They ran out of colors?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s because people blame lung cancer patients. They smoked, they screwed up, they deserve to die. The reason people die from lung cancer is guilt.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Huh. Well, guilt does a lot of damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said that with great significance.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re not here to find your stethoscope. You’re not here to clear your reputation. You’re here because you’re having doubts. You might have screwed up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m here because, if I’m right, Cuddy is killing that patient.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, but if you’re wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then she’s saving her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fine. You’re going to have to go through every record of every patient who’s been through this clinic in the last two days, and you’re gonna have to hope that those records can be trusted, which, by the way, yours can’t.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: These pills will help your kidneys function a little better, Sister. Get your wrist?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Is that good?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: You’re a lousy liar, Dr. Chase. [Chase’s beeper goes off. On it is the message “Call Mom!”

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I have to get this. Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: My mother’s been dead for 10 years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But she’s always with you in spirit. What do you know about the nun?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Which one?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The cute one. I think she likes me. The sick one, obviously.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Her parents died when she was a child and she’s been with the Church ever since.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s she lying about?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why do you say that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I always say that. And the old nun says the sick nun is a big fat nun liar. You know nuns, what do you think?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I don’t know nuns.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You hate nuns. You can’t hate someone if you don’t know them.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Know any Nazis? Maybe I hate them on principle.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have a theory on what makes good boys “good”. It’s not because of some moral imperative. Good boys have the fear of God put into them. Catholic Church specializes in that kind of training, to make good boys afraid of divine retribution so they will do what their daddies tell them, like, for example, going into medical school when it’s the last thing they want to do. What do you think?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think if she did have a secret, her boss would know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you paint, or put in new carpets recently?

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any way she could have got access to drugs?

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Well, we lock all of our medications in the infirmary, and we don’t keep prescription drugs here. Why haven’t you asked Sister Augustine about these things directly?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve found that when you want to know the truth about someone that someone is probably the last person you should ask.

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Ah. And have you been speaking to Sister Eucharist?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She ratted out her fellow sister pretty quickly. If I were you I’d have her repeat a year of nun school.

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Becoming a nun doesn’t make you a saint.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Becoming a doctor doesn’t make you a healer.

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Just because we live in a monastery and we spend most of our time in prayer doesn’t mean we don’t find time for drama.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, what is the sick one’s drama?

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Sister Augustine lived in Catholic foster care until she came to us. Tea?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. Do all of you lie? It’s a good strategy, simpler when you all tell the same lie, but she has not spent her entire life as a good Catholic. When she had a cardiac arrest I had to open her blouse to do CPR and I learned two things: nuns can have nice breasts, and she has a tattoo on her shoulder of a skunk. Now, maybe it’s the Sacred Skunk of Joseph, but as far as I know, Catholic foster care and monasteries do not keep tattoo parlors in their refractories.

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: We consider that our life begins when we put on our habits and take our vows. What happens before then –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is irrelevant to you, but it’s relevant to me.

utterance.speaker: Nun
utterance.content: Sister Augustine went into foster care when she was six years old, but she left when she was twelve. She lived on the streets, she got into drugs. When she was fifteen, she became pregnant, tried to self-abort. She lost the child, she became ill. We took her in when she came back. If we had thought it was medically relevant we would have told you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not. This tea is delicious. Local herbs?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Any change with medication?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, she’s getting worse. Lung function’s deteriorating, BUN and creatinine are continuing to rise. She’s starting to run a fever and the rash is spreading. At this rate she’s not going to make Christmas.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe House was right. Maybe there is an underlying condition that explains the symptoms, something we haven’t considered.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Like what?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It could be a metabolic disorder.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Specifically?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Mitogenetic.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Specifically?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m just saying –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re just saying you think House is right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Might be right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Of course he might be right! It might be the Hand of God at work. Don’t say it’s something else unless you’ve got something concrete to offer. What’s this, hemlock?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “I’m going to do you the biggest favor one doctor can do another. I’m gonna stop you from killing your patient.” It’s figwort tea. Great for that little pick-me-up we’re all looking for in the morning. Opens the lungs, increases the blood pressure, stimulates the heart. Unfortunately, if you then get injected with even 0.1 cc of epinephrine: instant cardiac arrest. Still, what the hell, it tastes great.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Sister Augustine –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Has been drinking it religiously, so to speak.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take the cardiac arrest out of the equation…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All the rest of the symptoms can be explained by a severe long-term allergic reaction.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s what Cameron said in the beginning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, she did. Well done. But your unwillingness to stick by your diagnosis almost killed this woman. Take a lesson from Foreman: stand up for what you believe. Okay, let’s go figure out how to save a nun.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Damned if you do, damned if you don’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because it’s been untreated for so long, it’s gone from a simple watery eyes, scratchy throat allergy to a whopping I’m-gonna-kick-your-ass allergy, compromising her immune system, diminishing her ability to heal and breaking down her organs systems. So, what’s the source?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The dish soap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, symptoms persisted days after the dishwashing episode. It’s gotta be something she’s been exposed to here in the hospital as well as the monastery.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, what about the tea? It caused her arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be, but it’s not definitive.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll skin test for allergens.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not yet, she’s too reactive. She’d test positive for everything. We need to stabilize her, isolate her from all possible allergens. Give her system a rest.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Get her in a clean room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. And we’ll gradually introduce allergens and see how she responds. When she reacts to something we’ll know that’s what killing her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There you go. No television, no books.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Not even my Bible?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m afraid not. This room has filtered air, filtered water… you even have silk sheets. Very decadent and hypoallergenic. You should be feeling better here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll be back to check on you in a little while.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Can the other sisters come in and pray with me?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’d be better if you don’t have any visitors. Once we isolate what’s causing your allergy, then we can be a little more lax. I can pray with you.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I want to die. Why has He left me?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I was in seminary school. They asked us once what our favorite passage was. I chose 1 Peter 1:7. “These trials only test your faith to see whether or not it is strong and pure. Your faith is being tested as fire tests gold and purifies it.”

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: “And your faith is far more precious to the Lord than pure gold; so if your faith remains strong after being tested, it will bring you much praise and glory and honor on the day of His return.”

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He hasn’t left you. The only thing in the way of your knowing if he’s left you is your fear. You have a choice: faith or fear. That’s the test.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Do you think faith doesn’t mean I won’t die?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It will affect how you experience your death, and therefore your life. It’s up to you.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Why did you leave seminary school.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A test. You passed. I didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’ll call you if anything changes.

utterance.speaker: Eucharist
utterance.content: Will she be all right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: As long as she’s not exposed to anything that will aggravate her allergy, she’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Need some help in here! Screw the procedure, she’s in anaphylactic shock!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No way, she’s in the damn clean room.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You kidding me? Get in here! 0.1 cc of epi.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Gonna have to intubate.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I got it. I’m in. Breathing’s stabilized.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s a clean room!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you get an allergic reaction in a clean room?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe it was the preservatives in the IV?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Checked that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Latex tubing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Checked that. Checked everything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, it could be mast-cell leukemia. It can cause anaphylaxis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Checked the blood levels. And it’s not eosinophilia or idiopathic anaphylasix.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe it’s just divine will.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not my will.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You do realize if you’re wrong, about the big picture that is, you’re going to burn, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do you want me to do? Accept it, pack it in?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. I want you to accept that sometimes patients die against all reason. Sometimes they get better against all reason.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, they don’t. We just don’t know the reason.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I don’t think the nuns would agree with you on that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I just wanted to say that I know that you did everything you could.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t need verification from you to know that I’m doing my job well. That’s your problem, not mine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was just being nice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, well, you don’t need to always do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Merry Christmas.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sister Augustine’s been extubated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s requested to check out against medical advice. She wants to go back to the monastery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, talk her out of it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think I may have talked her into it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Room’s paid up for the rest of the week. You might as well stick around.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: This illness is a test of my faith. If it’s His will to take me, it doesn’t matter where I am. I can accept that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does anybody believe anything you say? You’re not accepting. You’re running away. Just like you always do. You ran away from the monastery, you get laid, you ran away from the real world when getting laid didn’t work out so good. Now things aren’t working out again, so off you go.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Why is it so difficult for you to believe in God?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What I have difficulty with is the whole concept of belief. Faith isn’t based on logic and experience.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I experience God on a daily basis, and the miracle of life all around. The miracle of birth, the miracle of love. He is always with me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where is the miracle in delivering a crack-addicted baby? Hmmm? And watching her mother abandon her because she needs another score. The miracle of love. You’re twice as likely to be killed by the person you love than by a stranger.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Are you trying to talk me out of my faith?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can have all the faith you want in spirits and the afterlife, and heaven and hell, but when it comes to this world, don’t be an idiot. ‘Cause you can tell me you put your faith in God to put you through the day, but when it comes time to cross the road, I know you look both ways.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I don’t believe He is inside me and is going to save me. I believe He is inside me whether I live or die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you might as well live. You’ve got a better shot betting on me than on Him.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: When I was 15, I was on every kind of birth control known to man, and I still got pregnant. I blamed God. I hated Him for ruining my life, but then I realized something. You can’t be angry with God and not believe in him at the same time. No one can. Not even you, Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’d it go?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She has God inside her. It would have been easier to deal with a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe she’s allergic to God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We looked everywhere for an allergen that could be causing this reaction except one place: inside her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: On her medical history she didn’t mention any surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She had one.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can we get her records? What hospital was it at?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She didn’t have it at a hospital. Order a full body scan.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What if she refuses?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell her I’m looking for a miracle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No piercings, no fillings, no surgical pins in the arm, no implants…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s clean as a whistle. What’s House looking for?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What is that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lock on it. Get a 3D representation.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh my God!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The copper cross, a form of birth control pulled off the market in the 80s.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, she’s allergic to copper.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Rare, but it happens.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wouldn’t she know she had an IUD?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She had an abortion. IUD must have been left in, embedded in the endometrial tissue where it couldn’t be detected.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So, all we have to do is remove the IUD –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: -- and the symptoms should subside.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: I got this IUD when I was fifteen. It’s been more than twenty years.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Prolonged exposure to an allergen with minimal symptoms. But at some point, all it takes is one last contact to cause a full-blown reaction. It’s like a balloon filled with air. One last breath, it explodes.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: The first time I got the rash was when I was washing the copper cookware.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And all your subsequent symptoms came from ingesting food prepared in it.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: Dr. House found his miracle.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I doubt he’ll interpret it that way.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: You told me your favorite passage. Would you like to hear mine? . “Celebrate and be glad, for your brother was dead and is alive again.”

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The prodigal son.

utterance.speaker: Augustine
utterance.content: He’ll be waiting for you when you’re ready.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll schedule your surgery for tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The sixth circle of Hell.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Confined in a sweat box with a bloody nose and all the tissues are soggy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think that’s the seventh.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, seventh is –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: God, we must be fun at parties.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think we both know the flaw in that theory.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’s the Sister?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kidneys functioning, heart rate is normal. You know how it is with nuns: you take out their IUDs and they bounce right back.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told you I didn’t screw up.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You screwed up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I gave her 0.1 cc of epinephrine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, and if Cuddy hadn’t taken you off the case, you would have killed her. You want to come over for Christmas dinner?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re Jewish.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, Hanukkah dinner. What do you care? It’s food, it’s people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No thanks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe I’ll come to your place.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your wife doesn’t mind being alone at Christmas?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m a doctor, she’s used to being alone. I don’t want to talk about it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither do I.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You did good with the nun. Congratulations.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Merry Christmas, Dr. House. Dr. Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good night. That was sweet.
